films.info: A lot has been said about Zack Snyder's use of colors, but 300 might be his most recognizable work. This ultra-violent fantasy peplum uses the same ochre tones as the original graphic novel by Frank Miller.

films.title: Amélie Poulain
films.info: The entire film bathes in yellowish and greenish tones, a distinctive gimmick of director Jean-Pierre Jeunet. This effect used to be achieved chemically, but Amelie was the first film to be digitally color graded in France, back in 2001.

films.title: Blade Runner
films.info: Ridley Scott's dark and gloomy vision of Los Angeles in 2019 is reflected in its color palette, dominated by blue and ochre shades, as well as neon lights.

films.title: Frozen
films.info: Disney's highest grossing animated film of all time has, as expected, a cold and blue palette.

films.title:
Gone with
the Wind
films.info: The (so far) highest grossing film of all time is all about ochres, the color of the south. Still, we can notice an artistic use of red during the burning of Atlanta.

films.title:
Guardians of
the Galaxy
films.info: Marvel's most irreverent franchise is not as colorful as one could expect. However, the use of strong hues (especially vivid blues, purples and greens) is refreshing, along with the awesome soundtrack.

films.title: La La Land
films.info: Director Damien Chazelle's tribute to classic Hollywood musicals is all about colors. Costumes and sets tell a lot about the internal feelings of characters, as seasons pass by and Mia and Sebastian's love story goes downhill.

films.title:
Le Roi et
l'Oiseau
films.info: The King and the Mockingbird is the first French animated feature film. This 1979 masterpiece uses a light color palette to depict the Kingdom of Tachycardia and its disembodied architecture, delivering a sharp contrast to the darkness of the Lower City.

films.title:
Mad Max:
Fury Road
films.info: Director George Miller's post-apocalyptic car chase is a visual masterpiece. The palette is mostly orange, as the entire film takes place in the desert, but we can notice an interesting use of a blue filter as a day for night.

films.title: Mary Poppins
films.info: Early 20th century London was dark and grey, and so is 1964 Mary Poppins, with the notable exception of the animated sequence, dominated by pastel green hues.

films.title: Memento
films.info: In Memento, the colors serve the narrative purpose of the film, as director Christopher Nolan intertwines sequences edited in a reverse chronological order with black and white flashbacks in chronological order.

films.title: Moana
films.info: Disney's interpretation of Polynesian mythology is dominated by blue, turquoise and purple tones, which is not surprising considering that moana means ocean in polynesian languages.

films.title: Mommy
films.info: Director Xavier Dolan's coming-of-age drama stands out from the crowd with its 1:1 aspect ratio, but also with its use of strong colors: in particular, the yellowish tones of the house give us a feeling of intimacy as we dive into the lives of the Després family.

films.title: Mr. Nobody
films.info: Belgian director Jaco van Dormael's sci-fi drama uses different palettes to explore the alternate lives of Nemo Nobody, along with a desaturated color grading.

films.title: Speed Racer
films.info: Speed Racer is the very definition of colorful. To recreate the atmosphere of Japanese anime Mach GoGoGo, the Wachowskis chose to use computer-generated sets, leading to this kitsch, psychedelic, and deliberately unrealistic aesthetic.

films.title:
Star Trek
Into Darkness
films.info: J. J. Abrams' shiny (and lens-flary) vision of the future involves a light blue palette, like the corridors of the Enterprise. Fun fact: Star Trek Into Darkness had so many lens flares that Abrams had to ask Industrial Light & Magic to remove some of them digitally.

films.title:
Star Wars IV:
A New Hope
films.info: George Lucas' history-making film needs no introduction. As is to be expected from a space-opera, the palette is quite dark except for the scenes taking place on Tatooine.

films.title:
The Grand
Budapest Hotel
films.info: Director Wes Anderson is known for its use of light pastel colors, and The Grand Budapest Hotel is no exception, with its orange and rose hues.

films.title: The Matrix
films.info: In order to visually suggest the artificiality of the Matrix, the Wachowskis decided to use a greenish color grading on all scenes taking place inside the computer simulation, whereas the scenes set in the real world are usually dark blue.

films.title:
The Return
of the King
films.info: The final instalment of The Lord of the Rings trilogy is also the longest: 253 minutes(!) for the extended version. Its surprisingly colorful palette is dominated by ochre, greyish blue and green hues.

films.title:
The Wizard
of Oz
films.info: One of the earliest use of color as an artistic mean in a film: the scenes taking place in Kansas are shot in black and white (or rather in sepia), whereas the fantasy world of Oz is in Technicolor, with a predominance of yellow and green hues.

films.title: Tron
films.info: In his depiction of the inside of a computer, Tron undoubtedly represents a milestone in the use of CGI in films. A deeply innovative aesthetic, made of neon costumes and virtual sets, gives its electric blue color to the film.
